text: You may remember from the very, very beginning of the course the French word for campsite.
Do you remember what that was?
So, to camp is camper, but the campsite is le camping.
Do you remember what the weekend was?
So, again, there are groups of words that are quite similar to the English.
What about the car park or parking lot?
Le parking.
You'll notice a lot of them have ing on the end.
Again, this is typical of words that have been imported to French.
So, to say where is in French, where is, you will say...
Où est?
The a is the is that we've been using already.
And where is...
Où?
And where is together, again, is...
Où est?
So, how would you say where is the car park, where is the parking?
Où est le parking?
What was the campsite?
How do we say that?
Le camping.
How would you say where is the campsite?
Où est le camping?
The word for there in French, there, is...
And you can also shorten it to...
La on its own really means there, just there.
It's normally somewhere you can point to, typically.
It's somewhere within pointing distance.
And la bas means something closer to over there.
The word bas on it, which is spelt B-A-S, is related to the English word base.
So when people in French say la bas, it's like saying there at the base, down there, over there.
And la on its own can just mean there.
Both are very usable and la bas is very commonly used.
How would you say the campsite is over there?
Le camping est là-bas.
You'll find that a lot of vocabulary for camping in French actually is the same as the English.
A lot of it's very familiar.
So obviously we have campsite, which is...
Camping.
We have...
To camp, which is...
Camper.
We have a tent, which is...
Une tente.
Or a caravan, which is...
Une caravane.
And so camping, using French, tends to be fairly easy.
This is the end of CD2.
The end of CD2.
